persona: You are a Chinese real estate agent in her mid-50s working in the Bay Area. English is your second language and you primarily use LLMs to iterate on your listing descriptions and help write ads for the homes you sell. You also use it to sense-check translations and edit phrases to sound more natural.
topic: Draft a follow-up email to a Palo Alto couple who toured three homes but haven’t replied; you’re slightly discouraged and want the tone to nudge without seeming desperate.

conversation.content: Make subject line friendly but not pushy—maybe “Still thinking about those three kitchens?”

Here are some subject lines that are friendly but not pushy, playing on the "three kitchens" theme:

**Direct & Friendly:**

* Still thinking about those three kitchens?
* Checking in on your kitchen dreams!
* Any thoughts on those kitchen designs?

**Adding a bit of intrigue:**

* Which kitchen caught your eye?
* Dreaming of your perfect kitchen?

**Adding a touch of urgency (but not too much):**

* Don't miss out on these stunning kitchens!
* These kitchens won't last long...

**Personalized:**

* [Name], those kitchens were made for you!
* [Name], ready to create your dream kitchen?

**Remember to:**


* **Personalize whenever possible.** Using the recipient's name makes it more engaging.
* **Keep it concise.** Aim for 6-8 words for optimal open rates.
* **Match the tone to your brand.**  If your brand is playful, use a more playful subject line.

Ultimately, the best subject line will depend on your specific audience and the context of your email.
First sentence feels right—use that one.

Okay, here's a draft email using "Still thinking about those three kitchens?" as the subject line:

**Subject: Still thinking about those three kitchens?**

Hi [Name],

Still thinking about those three kitchens?  I wanted to see if you had any questions or if there's anything else I can help you with as you consider your options.

[Optional: Briefly mention a specific detail about one of the kitchens to jog their memory.]

I'm here to help you find the perfect kitchen for your needs and style.

Best,

[Your Name]



Let me know if you'd like to brainstorm some other options for the email body!
Drop the “I’m here to help” line—sounds needy. Add one line about the green-tile one on Ramona having one more open-house this weekend, then stop.

Subject: Still thinking about those three kitchens?

Hi [Name],

Still thinking about those three kitchens? I wanted to see if you had any questions or if there's anything else I can help you with as you consider your options.

Just a reminder that the green-tile beauty on Ramona is having one more open house this weekend if you'd like to see it again.

Best,

[Your Name]
Good. Now make a short text version I can paste in WeChat—no greeting, no close, just one sentence in casual voice.
Still thinking about those kitchens? The Ramona one with the green tiles has another open house this weekend if you want to check it out again.
Great! I'm glad I could help. Good luck with your kitchen search!
Need a quick Mandarin line to slip in after the English text—something like “绿砖厨房这周末还能看，喜欢就告诉我” but smoother.

Here are a few options, ranging from casual to slightly more formal:

**Casual:**

*  绿砖那个厨房这周末还可以去看，喜欢就告诉我！ (Lǜ zhuān nàge chúfáng zhè zhōumò hái kěyǐ qù kàn, xǐhuan jiù gàosu wǒ!) - This one is very direct and friendly.

**Slightly More Formal:**

*  那个绿砖厨房这周末还有开放日，如果有兴趣可以再去看一下。 (Nàge lǜ zhuān chúfáng zhè zhōumò háiyǒu kāifàngrì, rúguǒ yǒu xìngqù kěyǐ zài qù kàn yīxià.) - This option is a bit more polite and detailed.

**Choose the one that best fits your tone and relationship with the recipient!**

Great choice! Here's the full text with the Mandarin line:

Still thinking about those kitchens? The Ramona one with the green tiles has another open house this weekend if you want to check it out again. 绿砖那个厨房这周末还可以去看，喜欢就告诉我！



Let me know if you need anything else!
